title: Élie Metchnikoff
summary: Ilya Ilyich Mechnikov (Russian: Илья Ильич Мечников, also written as Elie Metchnikoff; 15 May [O.S. 3 May] 1845 – 15 July 1916)[1][note 1] was a Russian Imperial[2][3] zoologist of Romanian nobility ancestry[4] and Ukrainian Jewish[5] origin best known for his pioneering research in immunology.[6][7][8] He and Paul Ehrlich were jointly awarded the 1908 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine "in recognition of their work on immunity".[9] He was born, lived and worked for many years on the territory of Ukraine.[10] Given this complex heritage, four different nations and peoples justifiably lay claim to Mechnikov.[11]
